James Clarke Experienced Front-end Web Developer

Work Experience

  1. 1Zero Digital Ltd.

    Position held:
    Senior Front-end Developer
    Period of employment:
    April 2016 - Present

    As senior front-end developer for digital agency 1Zero I'm responsible for a large majority of the company's front-end output. I take wireframes and/or PSD mock-ups and turn them into fully-functional Umbraco websites. I'm also in charge of setting the standards of code quality for freelancers & contractors to follow. I'm currently learning ReactJS for an upcoming project for Dell.

    Examples of my work:

    • 1zero.co.uk
    • pukkaherbs.com
    • hartpury.ac.uk
    • vistair.com

  2. Firehoop Ltd. (later Spinasite Ltd.)

    Position held:
    Front-end Developer
    Period of employment:
    August 2013 - March 2016

    I worked in a team of 2 front-end devs who built all sites using the BEM naming syntax and a modular approach to Sass, which made the code easily scalable and simple for other developers to understand and maintain. I worked to tight deadlines to produce work exactly to the brief, either alone or as part of the team.

  3. Big Room Internet Ltd.

    Position held:
    Front-end Developer
    Period of employment:
    August 2008 - April 2013

    I was the sole front-end developer in a team of 3 people responsible for all of the websites that Big Room Internet produced. My daily work was focused predominantly on HTML and CSS, with occasional jQuery interactions. I was in charge of some of the client management and I conducted meetings with clients to discuss current and future projects. I had also taken charge of the future front-end development and was building the next generation of our master front-end framework, which included the use of HTML5, Sass and responsive design.

  4. Wolseley UK Ltd.

    Position held:
    Web Designer
    Period of employment:
    September 2006 - August 2008

    I was in a team of two who looked after the Intranet and many of the websites for the Wolseley UK brands and acquisitions. While at Wolseley, for several months my main duty was to upgrade many of their minor sites, which were built using tables-based layouts and turn them into more accessible, valid CSS-based sites.
